sub_topics: A manifold is a space that can be fully covered by a collection of local coordinate neighborhoods $U_i$ with bijective mappings $\phi_i: U_i \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^n$, called coordinate maps, where the collection of all charts ${(U_i, \phi_i)}$ is called a coordinate system or atlas of M. Integration on manifolds requires the manifold to be oriented, meaning it possesses a non-zero n-form at any point, allowing for consistent volume definition. The standard orientation of $\mathbb{R}^n$ is induced by the n-form $dx1 \wedge ... \wedge dxn.

The tangent space at a point p of a manifold M, denoted $T_pM$, can be defined intrinsically using equivalence classes of smooth curves $\gamma: (-\epsilon, \epsilon) \rightarrow M$, where $\gamma(0) = p$, eliminating the need to embed M in a larger space $\mathbb{R}^n$. Two curves are equivalent if they have the same range near p and the same parametrization near p.  This intrinsic definition is independent of any larger space in which the manifold is embedded, depending entirely on curves in the manifold M that pass through the point p. The tangent space $T_pM$ is defined as the set of all equivalence classes of curves at a point p, $T_pM = { [\gamma]_p | \gamma: (-\epsilon, \epsilon) \rightarrow M \text{ and } \gamma(0) = p }$. The velocity of the parametrization of the curve defines the tangent vector, so increasing the rate of change along the curve increases the velocity vector, allowing to distinguish between vectors of different magnitudes.

The push-forward of a vector $[\,\gamma\,]_p$ by a mapping $\phi$ is defined as the curve $\phi \circ \gamma$, denoted by $T\phi \cdot [\gamma]_p = [\phi \circ \gamma]_{\phi(p)}$, representing the transformation of the tangent vector through the mapping. Different notations can be used to represent the push-forward of a vector, including $T\phi \cdot [\gamma] = \phi_*([\gamma]) = \phi_* \cdot [\gamma] = [\phi \circ \gamma]$.  The pull-back of a differential form generalizes the notion of change of variables in integration, allowing forms to be integrated in different coordinates. The pull-back of a k-form $\omega_{\phi(p)} \in \Lambda_k(T^*_{\phi(p)}N)$ is defined as $T^*\phi \cdot \omega_{\phi(p)} \in \Lambda_k(T^*_pM)$, defined as $(T^*\phi \cdot \omega_{\phi(p)})(v_{p1}, v_{p2}, ..., v_{pk}) = \omega_{\phi(p)}(T_p\phi \cdot v_{p1}, T_p\phi \cdot v_{p2}, ..., T_p\phi \cdot v_{pk})$. The pull-back of a 1-form $\alpha_{\phi(p)} \in T^*_{\phi(p)}N$ is denoted by $T^*\phi \cdot \alpha_{\phi(p)}$ and acts on vectors $v_p \in T_pM$, defined as $(T^*\phi \cdot \alpha_{\phi(p)})(v_p) = \alpha_{\phi(p)}(T_p \cdot v_p)$, representing the transformation of the differential form from one tangent space to another through the mapping. For a 1-form $\alpha_{\phi(p)} \in T^*_{\phi(p)}N$, the pull-back is defined by $(T^*\phi \cdot \alpha_{\phi(p)})(v_p) = \alpha_{\phi(p)}(T_p \phi \cdot v_p)$, connecting the pull-back with the push-forward through the action on tangent vectors. The pullback of a function f: N \u2192 R is defined as $T\phi \cdot f = (f \circ \phi)(p) = f(\phi(p))$, reflecting how a function on N is transformed to a function on M under the mapping $\phi$.

Exterior differentiation acts on differential forms and generalizes the idea of directional derivatives from calculus, providing a way to differentiate forms on manifolds. The exterior derivative d possesses global existence and uniqueness, ensuring that the differentiation is consistent throughout the manifold. It is essential for the generalized Stokes' theorem, which relates the integral of a differential form over a manifold with the integral of its exterior derivative over the boundary of the manifold.

A partition of unity for a manifold M subordinate to a cover {$U_i$} is a collection of functions $\phi_i : M \rightarrow R$, where each $\phi_i$ is non-zero only on a subset of $U_i$, $0 \leq \phi_i(p) < 1$ for all $p \in U_i$, and $\sum_i \phi_i(p) = 1$ for all $p \in M$. The definition of the function $\phi_i$ subordinated to the coordinate patch $U_i$, with $0 \leq \phi_i(p) \leq 1$ for all $p \in U_i$ and $\sum_i \phi_i(p) = 1$ for all $p \in M$, used to decompose the differential form into a collection of differential forms subordinated to the coverage.

The tangent space $T_pM$ at a point p on a manifold M is the set of all tangent vectors at p, which can be intrinsically defined as equivalence classes of smooth curves passing through p. Intrinsic definition of tangent vectors as equivalence classes of smooth curves $\gamma: (-\epsilon, \epsilon) \rightarrow M$, where $\gamma(0) = p$, eliminating the need for extrinsic embedding in $\mathbb{R}^n$.

The equivalence relation between curves, where $\gamma_1 \sim \gamma_2$ if they are identical near p, and the definition of the equivalence class $[\,\gamma\,]$ as the set of all curves equivalent to $\gamma$, denoted by $[\,\gamma\,] = {\gamma' | \gamma' \sim \gamma}$. The tangent space $T_pM$ as the set of all equivalence classes of curves at p, formally defined as $T_pM = {[\gamma]_p | \gamma: (-\epsilon, \epsilon) \rightarrow M \text{ and } \gamma(0) = p }$.
The pushforward $T_p\phi$ maps tangent vectors from one tangent space to another, while the pullback $T^*\phi$ maps differential forms in the opposite direction.

The directional derivative of a function f: M \u2192 R in the direction of a vector v at p is defined as $v_p[f] = D[\gamma]_p f = [f \circ \gamma]|_{t=0}$, where $\gamma$ is a curve with velocity vector v at p. The connection between extrinsic and intrinsic views of tangent vectors through the derivative of $\gamma$ with respect to time evaluated at t = 0, essentially finding the Jacobian matrix of the mapping $\gamma: (-\epsilon, \epsilon) \rightarrow M$.  The use of the chain rule to express the directional derivative of a function f: M \u2192 R along a curve $\gamma$ as d(f \u25e6 \u03b3)/dt|t=0, connecting the directional derivative to the ordinary derivative of one variable.

The derivation of the formula for the directional derivative in local coordinates using a coordinate chart $\phi: U \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^n$, expressed as  $v_p[f] = D[\gamma]_p f = [f \circ \gamma]' = [f \circ \phi^{-1} \circ \phi \circ \gamma]' = [f \circ \phi^{-1}]_{\phi(p)} \cdot [\phi \circ \gamma]'$.
The importance of ensuring that the transition functions $\phi_j \circ \phi_i^{-1}$ have a positive Jacobian determinant to define a consistent volume form throughout M.

The push-forward of a vector $v \in T_pM$ by a mapping f: M \u2192 N is a vector $T_pf \cdot v \in T_{f(p)}N$, which represents how the mapping f transforms the vector v in the tangent space. The definition of the push-forward of a vector [\u03b3]p by a mapping \u03c6 as the curve \u03c6 \u25e6 \u03b3, denoted as T\u03c1\u03c6 \u00b7 [\u03b3]p = [\u03c6 \u25e6 \u03b3]\u03c6(p), and the alternative notation \u03c6\u2217(p)([\u03b3]p) = \u03c6\u2217(p) \u00b7 [\u03b3]p = \u03c6\u2217([\u03b3]p) \u2261 [\u03c6 \u25e6 \u03b3]\u03c6(p).

The more abstract definition of the push-forward of a vector [\gamma] by a mapping $\phi$ is the curve $\phi \circ \gamma$, i.e., $T_p\phi \cdot [\gamma] = [\phi \circ \gamma]_{\phi(p)}$, where the curve $\phi \circ \gamma$ represents how the mapping $\phi$ transforms the curve $\gamma$ in the tangent space.

The pullback of a differential form $\alpha \in T^*_{\phi(p)}N$ is a differential form $T^*\phi \cdot \alpha \in T^*_pM$, where the pullback is defined as $(T^*\phi \cdot \alpha)(v) = \alpha(T\phi \cdot v)$, which means that the pullback of a differential form acts on a vector and returns a scalar. The definition of the pull-back of a k-forma \u03c9\u03c6(p) \u2208 \u039b\u2096(T*\u03c6(p)N) as T*\u03c6 \u00b7 \u03c9\u03c6(p) \u2208 \u039b\u2096(T*pM), defined as (T*\u03c6 \u00b7 \u03c9\u03c6(p))(vp1, vp2, ..., vpk) = \u03c9\u03c6(p)(Tp\u03c6 \u00b7 vp1, Tp\u03c6 \u00b7 vp2, ..., Tp\u03c6 \u00b7 vpk).

The connection between push-forwards and pull-backs is that the push-forward of a vector is the vector transformed by the mapping, while the pull-back of a differential form is the differential form transformed by the mapping.
The pullback of a function f: N \u2192 R is defined as $T\phi \cdot f = (f \circ \phi)(p) = f(\phi(p))$, which means that the pullback of a function is the function composed with the mapping.

Exterior differentiation is a generalization of directional derivatives and is used to define the generalized Stokes' theorem, which relates the integral of a differential form over a manifold with the integral of its exterior derivative over the boundary of the manifold.
Lie differentiation acts on tensors and has a geometric interpretation that is easier to visualize than exterior differentiation.
Covariant derivatives generalize directional derivatives and require a connection on the manifold, which specifies how to transport tangent vectors in parallel from one tangent space to another.
An atlas is a collection of coordinate charts (Ui, $\phi_i$) that cover a manifold M, where each coordinate chart maps an open subset $U_i$ of M to an open subset of $\mathbb{R}^n$.

A partition of unity is a collection of functions $\phi_i: M \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ that are subordinate to a cover {$U_i$} of M and that satisfy the following conditions: (a) each $\phi_i$ is non-zero only on a subset V of $U_i$, (b) $0 \leq \phi_i(p) \leq 1$ for all $p \in U_i$ and (c) $\sum_i \phi_i(p) = 1$ for all $p \in M.
A volume form is an n-form that is not zero at any point of the manifold and is used to define an orientation on the manifold.
The integral of a differential form over a manifold is defined by pulling the differential form back to a Euclidean space and integrating it there.

The generalized Stokes' theorem relates the integral of a differential form over a manifold with the integral of its exterior derivative over the boundary of the manifold. The statement of the generalized Stokes theorem: $\int_M d\alpha = \int_{\partial M} \alpha$, where M is a smooth oriented n-dimensional manifold and $\alpha$ is an (n \u2212 1)-form on M, relating the integral of the exterior derivative of a form over a manifold to the integral of the form over its boundary.

The theorem of Stokes can be proved for a variety of manifolds using a bootstrap process, where the theorem is proved first for a simple case and then used to prove the theorem for more difficult cases. The strategy of proving the generalized Stokes theorem, starting with a specific and straightforward case and then using that simple case to prove more difficult cases, essentially “bootstrapping” up to the general version.
The proof of Stokes' theorem requires an understanding of the concept of orientation, which is a way to assign a direction to a manifold.
The proof of Stokes' theorem requires an understanding of the concept of a boundary, which is the set of points that are on the edge of a manifold.
Stokes’s Theorem is a powerful and useful instrument in mathematics and is used in various areas, including vector calculus, physics, and engineering.

The generalized Stokes' Theorem states that for a smooth oriented manifold M of dimension n and an (n-1)-form $\alpha$ on M, the integral of the exterior derivative of $\alpha$ over M is equal to the integral of $\alpha$ over the boundary of M ($\partial M$), where $\partial M$ is given the induced orientation.

Proofs of Stokes' Theorem are based on k-dimensional unit cubes (Ik) or k-simplexes, and the chapter uses visualization techniques developed to visualize what Stokes' Theorem is saying in three dimensions.  The use of k-dimensional unit cubes (Ik) as the basis for proofs of Stokes' theorem, with an emphasis on the orientations of these cubes and their boundaries.

A k-dimensional unit cube (Ik) is defined as the set of points (x1, ..., xk) where $0 \leq x_i \leq 1$ for all i = 1, ..., k. The orientation of Ik is determined by the volume form $dx1 \wedge ... \wedge dxk$. The definition of the orientation of k-dimensional unit cubes in terms of the volume form dx\u2081 \u2227 dx\u2082 \u2227 ... \u2227 dxk, and the notation for positive and negative orientations.

The boundary of a k-dimensional cube ($\partial Ik$) is the collection of all the faces of Ik, along with the orientation determined. Each face is given by $I_a(i)$, where a is 0 or 1, indicating that the coordinate xi is fixed at 0 or 1, respectively. The definition of the boundaries of a k-cube ($\partial Ik$) as the collection of all the faces of Ik, along with their determined orientations.
Exterior differentiation as a generalization of directional derivatives, acting on differential forms and leading to the generalized Stokes' theorem.
The global existence and uniqueness of the exterior differential operator d, ensuring that it exists and is unique throughout the manifold M.
The definition of an oriented n-dimensional manifold M as a manifold with an n-form that is non-zero at any point, allowing for the consistent definition of volumes.

The relation between the standard volume form $dx_1 \wedge ... \wedge dx_n$ and the Jacobian determinant of the transition functions $\phi_j \circ \phi_i^{-1}$, ensuring a consistent orientation throughout the manifold.
The concept of a partition of unity to decompose differential forms into a collection of differential forms subordinated to the cover, facilitating integration in coordinate patches.
